Authors:
Elena Bovio, Laura Garzoli, Anna Poli, Valeria Prigione,
Daria Firsova, Cristina Giovanna Varese, Grace McCormack
Title:
The culturable mycobiota associated with three Atlantic
sponges, including two new species: Thelebolus balaustiformis and
Thelebolus spongiae
Abstract:
Covering 70% of Earth, Oceans are at the same time the
most common and the less studied environment by microbiologists.
Considering the large gaps in our knowledge on the presence of marine
fungi in the oceans, the aim of this research was to isolate and
identify the fungal community within three species of sponges Dysidea
fragilis, Pachymatisma johnstonia and Sycon ciliatum, collected in the
Atlantic Ocean and never studied for the associated mycobiota. The use
of different isolation methods, incubation temperatures and media, also
mimicking the marine environment and sponges, were fundamental to
increase the number of cultivable taxa. Fungi were identified using a
polyphasic approach, by meaning of morpho-physiological, molecular and
phylogenetic techniques. The sponges revealed an astonishing fungal
diversity represented by 88 fungal taxa. Each sponge hosted a specific
fungal community with more than half fungi exclusive of each
invertebrates. Several taxa isolated and identified in this work were
first reported in marine environment (22 species) and in association
with sponges (49 species), including two new species Thelebolus xy MUT
2357 and Thelebolus xx MUT 2359, demonstrating that Oceans are an
untapped source of biodiversity. With the present work, we contributed
to add another tile in the great mosaic of marine microbial
diversity.
